summary: Type definition of workflow arguments is inconsistent between the `Workflow` type (using `any[]`) and `WithWorkflowArgs` type (using `[any, ...any[]]`), making it impossible to create generic types that extend `Workflow` while satisfying `WorkflowStartOptions`.
userImpact: Users cannot create reusable generic types that extend Workflow and work with WorkflowStartOptions due to type incompatibility.
rootCause: `any[]` type on Workflow interface is not assignable to `[any, ...any[]]` required by WithWorkflowArgs, causing type checking failures in generic scenarios.
proposedFix: Align the type definition of workflow arguments between Workflow and WithWorkflowArgs to use consistent tuple representation.
workaround: Define custom type extending `(...args: [any, ...any[]]) => Promise<any>` instead of extending Workflow type directly.
keyQuote: Due to `any[]` not being equal to `[any, ...any[]]`, the following example function will not pass type checking.
